<@U053PPGDC> do you guys track customers from webshop to app or do something similar?

Yeah it's part url, part cookiemanager

it isn’t session highjacking, it’s just analytics, but cookies can’t be accessed because of security

/gif voodoo

means  if they are in same domain

If in your case all your users use browsers with HTML5 support you can use window.postMessage method that allows to addEventListener on one side and to postMessage from the other. Here is a nice article/example: <https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/window.postMessage>.

Then the steps are simple:

add to site A a hidden iframe to site B
send B's cookie to A using window.postMessage
store the received cookie in A's cookie

attachments.title: Window.postMessage()
attachments.text: The window.postMessage method safely enables cross-origin communication. Normally, scripts on different pages are allowed to access each other if and only if the pages that executed them are at locations with the same protocol (usually both https), port number (443 being the default for https), and host (modulo document.domain being set by both pages to the same value). window.postMessage provides a controlled mechanism to circumvent this restriction in a way which is secure when properly used.

Yes <@U1F1JCBBM> , having an edittext doesn’t mean you have obligation to show keyboard. It’s default behaviour, but like contract16 says, you can override it with something like `android:windowSoftInputMode=“stateHidden”` in your manifest
